Graphical abstract The hydrodeoxygenation of oxygenates derived from lignin depolymerization is essential to obtain aromatic platform hydrocarbons such as benzene. In this work, potential of HDO of lignin prototype guaiacol was explored by enhancing the synergy of nickel (Ni) and cobalt (Co) in a bimetallic catalyst supported over alumina for a distinct catalytic activity and selectivity. The hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of guaiacol was investigated in a batch reactor using Ni-Co/γ-Al2O3 catalysts prepared by co-impregnation method. The structural and physicochemical properties of the catalysts were investigated using BET, XRD, H2-TPR, FT-IR, and NH3-TPD. The characterization results revealed that the formation of various Ni-Co composite species strongly depend on the Ni/Co mole ratio, total metal loadings, and the calcination/reduction temperature. The 6.1Ni3.05CoAl (Ni/Co = 1:2) catalyst seeds the formation of NiCo2O4 spinel structure and subsequent formation of Ni-Co alloy, which represents as specific active site for direct demethoxylation/deoxygenation reaction. The synergistic interaction of Ni-Co enhances the selectivity of benzene. The benzene selectivity of 35.2 % and cyclohexane selectivity of 59.1 % with complete conversion of guaiacol (98.9 %) were achieved with the 3.05Ni6.1CoAl catalyst at 575 K. A tentative reaction pathway is proposed based on the product distribution accomplished during HDO reaction. The structural property was correlated with activity to explore the mechanistic insights. Keywords Hydrodeoxygenation Guaiacol Ni-Co/Al2O3 catalyst Ni-Co alloy Ni/Co mole ratio Aromatics 1 Introduction Since past few years, greener alternative forms of energy and commodity chemicals have been visioned to serve the needs of human society due to the limited fossil fuels reserve and allied environmental concerns for its increasing consumption. Amongst, lignocellulosic biomass emerged as the potential alternative to petroleum-based fossil fuels. It is expected that the chemical and physical properties of bio-oil generated from lignocellulosic biomass can be similar or better than petroleum if upgraded properly [1]. Similarly, “lignin,” the third component of lignocellulosic biomass and the second most abundant polymer available in nature has been envisioned as a renewable source for aromatic based platform chemicals [2]. The structural features of lignin represent the aromatic rings randomly held together by strong CC and CO bonds to adopt a polyaromatic configuration. Thus, depolymerization of lignin has the potential to directly replace building block aromatic chemicals such as benzene, xylene, and toluene (BTX) from petroleum refineries. BTX is used as a feedstock for the production of a wide range of bulk chemicals [3]. Thus, BTX has great market opportunities and deriving them directly from abundant renewable source lignin has potential economic benefits [2]. However, the recent studies which have been devoted to depolymerization of lignin suggest that the product stream majorly contains oxygenated aromatic monomers, which makes them unsuitable for direct utilization [4]. Therefore, further up-gradation of lignin-derived bio-oil is essential to remove the oxygen functionality and to refine their properties. Catalytic hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) is considered to be the most effective route for upgrading and removing the oxygen functionality from lignin-derived bio-oil or the compounds present in bio-oil. Guaiacol is frequently selected model compound for the up-gradation studies mainly because of its occurrence in bio-oil in high fraction and existence of three types carbon-oxygen linkages: C(sp3)-OAr, C(sp2)-OMe (methoxy), and C(sp2)−OH (hydroxyl) [5]. In recent years, several catalysts have been utilized in the HDO of guaiacol, which completely or partially removes oxygen functionality from the product compound. Supported noble metal (s) catalysts (Rh, Ru, Pt, Pd) have been extensively studied for the HDO of guaiacol [6,7]. However, the application of these catalysts is not economically feasible and industrially acceptable due to their high cost and scarcity. Another disadvantage associated with the noble metals based catalysts are high H2 consumption, which leads to higher selectivity for hydrogenated products. Several non-noble transition metal catalysts (Ni, Fe, Co, Cu, Mo) were also developed and utilized in the HDO of guaiacol [8,9]. The nickel (Ni) as active metal has been most commonly studied for the HDO of different bio-oil model compounds because of its low cost, wide availability, and good hydrogenation performance. The Ni-based catalysts exhibited superior guaiacol HDO activity and selectively produced ring hydrogenated products such as cyclohexane, cyclohexene, and cyclohexanol. For example, Dongil et al. investigated the HDO of guaiacol over carbon nanotubes supported Ni nanoparticles as catalyst at 533 K and 5 MPa H2 pressure [10]. The authors reported that the selectivity of hydrogenated products such as cyclohexene or cyclohexane depends on whether Ni nanoparticles are located inside or outside carbon nanotubes. Another study comprising of HDO of guaiacol and phenol over Ni/SiO2-ZrO2 catalyst at 573 K and 5 MPa hydrogen pressures, cyclohexane was obtained as the dominant product [11]. Recently, Zhang et al. also studied the HDO of phenolic compounds (phenol, anisole, guaiacol, eugenol, cresol, and vanillin) over Ni/SiO2 and Ni/Al2O3 catalysts at 573 K and 5 MPa H2 pressure [12]. They reported that with both the catalysts cyclohexane was obtained as the major product during the HDO of phenol. Fe is another inexpensive and widely available metal that possesses promising HDO activity and less H2 consumption preventing hydrogenation of aromatic ring. Olcese et al. studied the HDO of guaiacol over Fe/SiO2 in a flow reactor in the temperature range of 623−723 K under H2 pressure [13]. They obtained partially deoxygenated phenol as the major product and 38 % yield for unsaturated products such as benzene and toluene with 74 % conversion of guaiacol. Consequently, supported monometallic transition metal catalysts often show lower deoxygenation capacity, uncontrolled hydrogenation of aromatic ring, and coke formation. Nevertheless, modification of the geometric and electronic structure of monometallic catalysts with the addition of an appropriate second metal improves the catalytic performance due to the synergistic effect between the metals [14]. Therefore, various transition metals such as Fe, Mo, Co, Cu have often been used as an additive to increase the catalytic activity and stability of Ni-based catalysts. Fang et al. studied the gas-phase HDO of guaiacol at 573 K with 3 MPa H2 pressure using carbon nanotubes (CNT) supported Ni, Fe, and Ni-Fe catalysts [15]. The bimetallic Ni-Fe/CNT catalyst showed the higher activity compared to monometallic counterparts because of the strong interactions (metal-metal and metal-support) between Ni, Fe, and support. The selectivity towards phenol or cyclohexane was dependent on metallic particle size and Ni/Fe atomic ratio of the catalyst. The Ni-Fe catalysts supported on various supports were also studied for HDO of guaiacol by Xu et al. [16]. The HY supported Ni-Fe catalyst achieved the highest selectivity for BTX yield (14 %) with phenols as the dominant product. Similar to Ni-Fe, a combination of Ni and Mo has been extensively studied for the HDO of guaiacol [11]. The authors reported that the active sites for the HDO of guaiacol are metallic nickel and partially reduced Mo4+ (MoO2). The relative amount of these two active species is strongly dependent on the Ni/Mo mole ratio and reduction temperature. An optimum fraction of Ni/Mo4+ species was obtained at an equal molar ratio of Ni and Mo which results in higher HDO activity and selectivity to phenol. Recently, HDO of guaiacol was evaluated over Ni and Ni-Cu catalysts at 573 K and 5 MPa H2 pressure [17]. It was reported that the addition of Cu to Ni reinforced the acidity of the SiO2-ZrO2 supported bimetallic catalyst by inducing the formation of strong acid sites on the catalyst surface and hence, the product distribution. The addition of Cu decreases the selectivity towards cyclohexane and favors the formation of methylated products (methyl-cyclohexane, toluene, and xylene). In another study, Cu and Co modified Ni catalysts supported over HZSM-5 was tested in the HDO of phenol at 523 K and 50 bar H2 pressure [18]. This report suggested that the addition of Cu to Ni played a detrimental role in the activity of the catalysts as compared to Co. Although, both Cu and Co were found to form alloys with Ni, however, Cu caused a loss of active sites via segregation of Cu species at the surface whereas addition of Co leads to the formation of finely dispersed and strongly stabilized active Ni sites. A complete phenol conversion and 99.3 % selectivity for deoxygenated product was obtained over 10Ni10Co catalyst with cyclohexane as the major product. The incorporation of Co to Ni also increases the coke resistance as compared to Ni/HZSM-5 catalyst. Some previous studies also reported the suppression of coke formation upon addition of Co to Ni, thus, providing better stability under reaction conditions. Recently, Zhou et al. investigated the HDO of guaiacol over γ-Al2O3 and HZSM-5 supported Ni-Co catalysts [19]. The authors reported that NiCo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst with equal metal loadings exhibited better activity and about 96 % of guaiacol was converted to cyclohexanol as the major product at 473 K and 5 Mpa H2 pressure. Tran et al. also investigated the HDO of guaicol over Al-MCM-41 supported Ni-Co catalyst in a fixed reactor system [20]. A high proportion of gasous product (mainly C1 products including CH4, CO and CO2) were observed at 673 K under ambient pressure. The important conclusions drawn in various previous reports as discussed above express the incapability of the catalysts to cleave CAr−OH bond, which leads to the formation of partially deoxygenated products, limit the hydrogenation of the aromatic ring of guaiacol and or intermediate products, and coke formation. Therefore, great potential lies in the development of an advanced multifunctional catalyst with a high degree of deoxygenation activity and controlled hydrogenation capability meaning limiting the hydrogenation of aromatic ring. The design of such catalyst could also help in the development of the process for the production of aromatic based platform chemicals directly from lignin and or lignin-derived compounds. In the present investigation, cobalt (Co) was considered as a modifier to develop alumina (γ-Al2O3 (Al)) supported Ni-Co catalysts for the HDO of guaiacol. The HDO of guaiacol reactions were performed in the high temperature and pressure batch reactor considering different process parameters. The Ni-Co/Al catalysts with varying total metal loadings, and metals (Ni/Co) molar ratios were prepared and characterized by a number of techniques to explore the structural and physicochemical characteristics of surface active species formed in the catalyst and interaction of Ni and Co. The synergistic effect between Ni and Co on the HDO activity and selectivity of products is elucidated by correlating the structure and reactivity of the Ni-Co catalysts. A comprehensive reaction pathway was suggested based on the formation and distribution of various products under varying reaction conditions and using different Ni-Co catalysts. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials Nickel nitrate hexahydrate [Ni(NO3)2.6H2O, Purity ≥99.99 %], and cobalt nitrate hexahydrate [Co(NO3)2, 6H2O, Purity ≥99.99 %] metal precursors were procured from Sigma-Aldrich. γ-Al2O3 pellets (1/8″ diameter, purity 99.9 %) and 2-methoxy phenol (guaiacol, purity ≥98 %) were procured from Alfa Aesar. 1,2,3,4-tetrahydronaphthalene (tetraline, 98 %) was procured from SRL Chemicals Pvt. Ltd, India. All chemicals were used as received without further treatment. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Monometallic Ni, Co, and bimetallic Ni-Co catalysts of varying composition supported over γ-Al2O3 were prepared by the co-impregnation method. The pretreatment of as received alumina was performed under similar conditions of catalyst preparation to remove any residual impurities, that may present and allow for morphological/textural changes before impregnating the active metal/metal oxide under similar conditions. The γ-Al2O3 was initially treated with the millipore water equal to the incipient volume of support. The wet support material was kept overnight for drying at room temperature followed by at 383 K in a hot air oven for 6 h. The dried material was then, calcined in air at 723 K (heating rate 1 K/min) for 6 h. After calcination, the pretreated γ-Al2O3 was crushed to powder. The calculated amount of metal precursor (s) corresponding to particular metal (s) loading was dissolved in pretreated support incipient volume of millipore water to prepare metal (s) precursor solution. The metal precursor (s) solution was then added to the pretreated support and stirred for 1 h to ensure proper mixing. The resulting thick paste was dried overnight at room temperature followed by at 383 K in a hot air oven for 6 h. Finally, the oven dried material was ground to a fine powder and calcined in air at 723 K (heating rate 1 K/min) for 6 h. The calcined samples were reduced in flow of H2 (50 mL/min) at 723 K for 3 h in a horizontal tubular furnace and transferred carefully to the batch reactor with limiting exposure to air for reaction studies. The total metal (s) loading in the prepared catalysts was varied in the range of 0.9–11.1 mmolgcat −1. For the catalyst with total metal loadings beyond 3.0 mmolgcat −1, a two-step co-impregnation method was followed for the impregnation of corresponding metal precursor (s). The final catalysts are designated as xNiyCoAl, where x and y represent the mmol of Ni and Co per gram of catalyst, respectively. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The specific surface area of the Ni-Co catalysts and alumina support was measured by N2 adsorption/desorption studies at 77 K performed in Micromeritics ASAP2020 physisorption analyzer. Before the analysis, the degassing of samples was performed at 473 K under vacuum (10−5 torr) for 2 h to remove adsorbed moisture/gases and any other impurities, that may present. The N2 isotherm data of adsorption branch in the relative pressure (P/Po) range of 0.05 to 0.3 were utilized for the calculation of surface area using the multipoint Brunauer-Emmet-Teller (BET) equation. Pore volume of the catalysts was evaluated by considering the adsorbed liquid nitrogen volume at P/Po = 1.0 (approx). Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis of the Ni-Co catalysts was performed using Rigaku SmartLab Diffractometer operated at 40 kV voltage and 40 mA current using CuK α monochromatized radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) and D/teX Ultra 250 detector. The diffraction pattern of all the samples was recorded in the 2θ range of 10° to 90° with a scanning speed of 2°min−1. The crystallite sizes of the alumina supported Ni, Co and Ni-Co catalysts were also calculated using Debye-Scherrer equation from the full width at half maximum (FWHM) of primary diffraction peak for Ni and Co metal or metal oxide in monometallic and Ni-Co mixed oxide or alloy in bimetallic catalyst [21]: D = R × λ β × cos θ Where, D, R, λ, θ, and β represent the crystallite size (Å), Scherrer constant (0.89), the wavelength of the X-ray (1.5408 Å), the diffraction angle, and the full width at half maximum (FWHM), respectively. H2-temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) analysis of the catalysts was carried out in Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 chemisorption analyzer. The U-shaped quartz tube was charged with about 20 mg of freshly calcined sample supported by two layers of quartz wool and placed inside the furnace. Then, the degassing of the sample was carried out at 473 K for 1 h in flowing (30 mL min−1) of argon to remove physically adsorbed moisture/gases or any other impurities. After the degassing, the temperature of sample was brought down to 373 K in flow of argon. Afterward, the sample was heat treated from 373 to 1073 K using a heating rate of 10 Kmin−1 in flow of 10 vol% H2/Ar (50 mL min−1) gas mixture. A thermal conductivity detector (TCD) quantitatively measured the hydrogen consumption. Fourier Transform Infrared spectrum (FT-IR) of the oxidized catalysts under ambient condition was recorded in transmission mode on a Bruker TENSOR 37 FTIR spectrometer. The IR spectrum was recorded in the wavenumber range of 400–4000 cm−1 with average of 256 no of scans and a resolution of 4 cm−1. A transparent circular disk containing powdered oxide catalysts spectroscopic grade KBr was made using a hydraulic press. All the IR spectra were acquired against a KBr background. NH3 temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) studies for reduced Ni-Co catalysts were carried out using Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 chemisorption analyzer. Firstly, the degassing of reduced catalyst sample was performed at 473 K for 1 h under the continuous stream of pure helium (He) gas (20 ml min−1). The sample was then cooled down to 373 K. Then, 10 vol% NH3–He gas mixture (20 ml min−1) was introduced into the reactor and continued the flow for 1 h. The flow of gas mixture was then changed to pure He (50 ml min−1) and the flow was continued for 1 h to ensure removal of physically adsorbed ammonia from the catalyst. The catalyst sample was therefore heated up to 1073 K with a heating rate of 10 K min−1 and the amount of NH3 desorbed from the catalyst was continuously monitored using a TCD detector. The quantity of acid sites was calculated using the amount of NH3 desorbed and pulse calibration data collected separately using same gas mixture. 2.4 HDO reaction of guaiacol The catalytic HDO of guaiacol was performed in a high-pressure and temperature stainless steel batch reactor (Capacity = 300 mL, Parr Instruments, USA, Model no: 4566HT). The batch reactor is fitted with four-bladed magnetic drive stirrer, pressure gauge and controller module for controlling reaction temperature, and stirrer speed (Model no: 4848). The freshly reduced catalyst was immediately transferred to the reaction mixture to avoid the possibility of air oxidation for each experiment. The liquid reactant feed, consisting of 5 wt% guaiacol in tetralin as a solvent was introduced into the batch reactor. The reactor was then made tight firmly by split ring closure and purged with hydrogen gas for several times to remove confined air inside the reactor. After purging, the reactor vessel was filled with hydrogen (H2) gas equal to the desired initial pressure at ambient temperature. The reactor vessel was then placed in a ceramic tubular heater and heated up to the desired reaction temperature under stirring condition. The agitator speed of 1000 rpm was maintained to eliminate the diffusional resistance. After attaining the desired reaction temperature, the first liquid sample was drawn and considered as the start time for the reaction. During the course of the reaction, liquid samples were drawn pat 0, 5, 15, 30, 60, 120, 240 min of reaction time. After 4 h of reaction time, the ceramic tubular heater was removed, and the reactor vessel was left for cooling in air up to room temperature. The collected gas sample was analyzed using Agilent 490 Micro GC packed with PoraPLOT U and Molesieve 5A column with a TCD. The reactor was then depressurized, and the reaction mixture was filtered to recover the spent catalyst. The spent catalyst was thoroughly washed with ethanol for 3–4 times to remove the adhered reaction mixture and dried in a hot air oven at 343 K for 6 h. Reusability studies of spent catalysts were performed after collecting the catalyst for few runs carried out at similar conditions. The regeneration capability of the spent catalyst was examined by performing an experimental run with the spent catalyst heat treated in air at 723 K for 6 h followed by H2 reduction at 723 K for 3 h. All the liquid samples collected were firstly centrifuged and the suspended catalyst particles (if any) were removed by filtering through a nylon syringe filter. The liquid sample was then quantitatively analyzed using a gas chromatograph (GC, Agilent 7890B) fitted with flame ionization detector (FID) and DB-Wax capillary column (30 m × 0.32 mm × 0.25 μm), and nitrogen as carrier gas. The GC oven temperature was initially maintained at 313 K for 2 min and, then was gradually increased to 333 K using a heating rate of 5 K/min and maintained temperature for 1 min. Again, the oven temperature was further increased to 513 K using a heating rate of 5 K/min and maintained this temperature for 5 min. The injector and detector temperatures were kept at 513 K and 523 K, respectively. The various products formed both in liquid phase during HDO of guaiacol were identified by gas chromatograph mass spectrometry (Shimadzu, GC–MS QP2010 Ultra) and comparing the mass spectra of each compound with the standard library of NIST and Wiley. The products identified were further reconfirmed by comparing the retention time of peaks obtained by injecting the respective pure compounds in GC-FID. The conversion of guaiacol (%) and product selectivity (%) was calculated from: C o n v e r s i o n % = n g u 0 - n g u i n g u 0 × 100 S e l e c t i v i t y % = n p r o d u c t i n t o t a l × 100 Y i e l d % = n p r o d u c t i n g u o × 100 Where n g u 0 is the initial moles of guaiacol in the reaction mixture, n g u i is the moles of guaiacol at time t, n p r o d u c t i is the moles of particular product i and n t o t a l is the moles of total product. The turnover frequency (TOF) was calculated with the initial moles of guaiacol in mol ( n g u 0 ), the guaiacol conversion ( X g u ), amount of Ni and/or Co in mol ( n N i , C o ) and the dispersion (D) [22]. T O F = n g u a X g u a 100 t i m e h - 1 D × n N i Where D was derived from the mean particle size calculated using Scherrer Equation [15,22,23]. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization The BET surface area of calcined and reduced xNiyCoAl catalysts along with the respective Tmax values obtained from TPR studies are tabulated in Table 1 . The surface area of pure γ-Al2O3 (calcined at 773 K) was 226 m2/g. The impregnation of Ni and/or Co over γ-Al2O3 resulted in a significant decline in surface area of reduced and oxidized catalysts as compared to pure γ-Al2O3. This is due to the surface coverage and partially occupied pores of γ-Al2O3 by nickel oxide and cobalt oxide or metallic nickel and cobalt crystallites and pore blockage phenomena often observed in impregnation method [24]. The supported monometallic 9.2NiAl and 9.2CoAl catalysts possess surface area of 137 m2/g and 128 m2/g, respectively. Among the calcined catalysts with different Ni/Co mole ratios, 9.2CoAl exhibited the lowest surface area, which might be due to slightly larger ionic radius of Co2+ (0.72 Å) than Ni2+ (0.69 Å) [25]. The specific surface area was unaffected or not followed a specific trend with the variation of molar composition of Ni and Co in the bimetallic catalyst. Furthermore, an increase in total metal loading of Ni and Co from 0.9 to 11.1 mmolg−1 cat (at constant Ni/Co mole ratio of 1:2) in calcined xNiyCoAl catalysts resulted in the decline of surface area from 220 to123 m2 g−1. The decline in surface area with the enhancement of total metal loading might be because of the pore-blocking phenomenon commonly observed in the impregnation method [24]. It could also be observed that the surface area of the 3.05Ni6.1CoAl catalyst decreased from 157 to 135 m2 g-1 with the rise in the calcination temperature from 623 to 823 K. The decline in surface area with the rise in calcination temperature might be because of the gradual sintering and growth of crystallite size as shown in Table 1 [26]. All reduced γ-Al2O3 supported Ni, Co, Ni-Co catalysts demonstrated higher surface area in comparison to calcined catalysts, which might be because of the redistribution of respective metal (s) on support surface during reduction process [27]. The powder XRD patterns of the calcined xNiyCoAl catalysts with different Ni(x)/Co(y) metal mole ratio at a constant total metal loading of 9.2 mmolg−1 cat are displayed in Fig. 1 (a) and Table S1. For the comparison purpose, the XRD patterns of bulk NiO and Co3O4 were also obtained and are shown in Fig. 1(a). The bulk NiO displayed the characteristic diffraction peaks for NiO (Table S1). Whereas, bulk Co oxide displayed the characteristic diffraction peaks attributed to Co3O4. The 9.2NiAl catalyst exhibits characteristic diffraction peaks for nickel oxide (NiO) and nickel aluminate (NiAl2O3) [28,29]. For 9.2CoAl catalyst, the diffraction peaks corresponding to cobalt aluminate (Co2AlO4) and cobalt oxide (Co3O4) were detected [26]. Due to similar cubic structures, both phases almost have the same XRD pattern [29]. With the decrease in Ni content or Ni/Co mole ratio, the intensity of the peaks centered at around 37.23° (0 0 3), 43.27° (0 1 2) and 62.83° (1 0 4) corresponding to NiO decreases and completely disappeared in 3.05Ni6.1CoAl catalyst (Ni/Co mole ratio of 1:2). On the other hand, the diffraction peaks at 2θ = 36.86° (3 1 1), 44.81° (4 0 0) and 65.35° (4 4 0) attributed to Co3O4 gradually shifted towards lower angle with the decrease in Ni/Co mole ratio or increase in Co content in Ni-Co catalysts. However, formation of cobalt aluminate cannot be ruled out as the 2θ values of some of the signature peaks are very close to Co3O4. These variations in the intensity and position of diffraction peaks clearly indicate local interactions between Ni and Co species and due to similar unit cell structure. The appearance of diffraction peaks corresponding to the presence of nickel dicobalt(III) oxide (NiCo2O4) spinel clearly identified in 3.05Ni6.1CoAl catalyst. The lower diffraction angle of NiCo2O4 as compared to Ni and Co in the diffraction pattern is due to the larger value of its lattice constant [30]. Therefore, the partial transformation of Ni and Co oxide to the NiCo2O4 phase strongly depends on the Ni/Co mole ratio of the catalysts. Moreover, the addition of Ni to Co in the bimetallic catalysts reduced the crystallite size than its monometallic counterparts (Table 1) [31]. These results confirmed that the composite oxide phase was formed due to the solid phase reaction of Ni and Co oxides. This composite oxide appears to be the precursor for the formation of Ni-Co alloy during the reduction process as discussed in the subsequent section. The powder XRD patterns of reduced xNiyCoAl catalysts of different Ni and Co mole ratios are presented in Fig. 1(b) and Table S2. The reduced 9.2NiAl catalyst revealed typical diffraction pattern of metallic nickel [32]. Whereas, the low-intensity diffraction peaks corresponds to surface oxidized Ni species (NiO) which might form after exposure to air and or nickel oxide might have not reduced completely. For 9.2CoAl catalyst, diffraction peaks corresponding to metallic cobalt were noticed [33]. The diffraction peaks of reduced Ni-Co bimetallic catalysts do not match precisely with the characteristics diffraction peaks of Ni and Co metal. As can be seen, the most substantial diffraction peaks characteristics of metallic Ni and Co were noticed at 2θ value of 44.46° (1 1 1), and 44.21° (1 1 1) [34]. More emphasis on the XRD patterns in the 2θ of range between 43° and 46° (shown as insert) revealed that in Ni-Co bimetallic catalyst, the peak was located between metallic Ni and Co. Also, this peak was noticed to gradually reposition towards lower angle (from the 2θ value of Ni to Co) with a decline in Ni/Co ratio or enhancement of Co content, suggesting the formation of Ni-Co alloy during reduction. Therefore, alloys with varying compositions of Ni and Co may formed at different Ni/Co mole ratio; and in the case of the samples enriched with Co, Ni could be embedded in larger Co areas as a result of the formation of spinel phase (NiCo2O3) [18]. The XRD pattern of 7.3Ni1.8CoAl catalyst exhibits diffraction peaks corresponding to metallic nickel and cobalt-nickel alloyed phase. A further increase in Co content in 6.9Ni2.3CoAl reflected the peaks corresponding to nickel-cobalt alloy were observed. The catalyst sample with a Ni/Co molar ratio of 1:2 (3.05Ni6.1CoAl) showed the shifted peak location at 2θ = 44.36° (1 1 1), which could be assigned to Ni-Co alloyed phase with the composition (Co3Ni7)0.4 [35]. The other peaks corresponding to metallic nickel phase (51.85°, and 76.38°) were also shifted towards lower 2θ value with reduced intensities associated with the Ni-Co alloyed phase at 51.65 (2 0 0) and 75.86 (2 2 0) with the increase in Co content suggesting an increase in metal-metal interaction rather than the metal-support interactions in the bimetallic catalyst [35]. These results are also consistent with the previous reports, which suggested the occurrence of a single characteristic diffraction peak in this region (43−47°) for the supported Ni-Co catalyst because of the formation of Ni-Co alloy [21,34,36–38]. Therefore, Ni-Co metal alloy forms in the Ni-Co catalyst depending on the Ni/Co mole ratio. The crystallite size of monometallic 9.2NiAl and 9.2CoAl catalysts was estimated to be about 18.0 and 17.0 nm (Table 1). Among the xNiyCoAl bimetallic catalysts, the 3.05Ni6.1CoAl catalyst exhibited the largest crystallite size of 20.5 nm, which might be due to the formation of Ni-Co alloy. A few previous reports have also suggested an enlargement of the crystallite size because of the formation of metal alloy [38,39]. The powder XRD patterns of the calcined catalyst with various total metal loading ranging from 0.9 to 11.1 mmolg−1 cat at constant Ni and Co mole ratio of 1:2 are shown in Fig. S1 and Table S3. The catalyst sample with a lower metal loading of 0.9 mmolg−1 cat (0.3Ni0.6CoAl) displayed diffraction pattern associated with nickel oxide (NiO2) and cobalt nickel oxide (Co2NiO4). However, with increase in the total metal loading of the catalyst from 0.9 mmolg−1 cat to 4.2 mmolg−1 cat, the all overall diffraction pattern and precisely broad peaks located at 2θ angle of 46° and 66.69° gradually shifted towards lower angle. With further increase in total metal loading, typical diffraction peaks of NiCo2O4 spinel phase instigate in the samples with a total metal loading of 5.7 mmolg−1 cat (1.9Ni3.8CoAl) whereas sharp reflections corresponding to nickel dicobalt (III) oxide (NiCo2O4) spinel phase was clearly observed in the sample with a total metal loading of 9.2 mmol/g. A further increase in metal loading to 11.1 mmol/g leads to the formation of cobalt-nickel oxide with a composition of Co1.29Ni1.71O4 as the major phase in the catalyst sample. These results suggest that the formation of NiCo2O4 spinel phase strongly depends on the total metal loading of the catalyst as well. The powder XRD pattern of all supported Ni-Co reduced catalysts with various total metal loadings of 0.9–11.1 mmolg−1 cat at a constant Ni, and Co mole ratio of 1:2 are shown in Fig. S2 and Table S4. The catalyst sample with the least total metal loading of 0.9 mmolg−1 cat (0.3Ni0.6CoAl) showed diffraction peaks associated with metallic cobalt and nickel-cobalt alloyed phase with a composition of Co0.75Ni0.25. However, an increase in the total metal loading results in the disappearance of the diffraction peaks at 39.40° (1 1 4) and 44.31° (0 0 2) and commencing of sharp and strong diffraction peaks at 2θ range of 36.9°, 44.3°, 51.6°, and 66.5°. By enlarging the 2θ angle from 43°-48°, it was observed that as the total metal loading increased, the diffraction peaks attributed to the features of partially substituted Ni and Co metallic species (44.44° and 44.98°) shifted towards an intermediate 2θ angle (44.3°). These reflections do not comply with the characteristic reflections of Ni or Co metal indicating the possible interaction between Ni and Co metallic species with the change in total metal loading. For the total metal loading of 9.2 mmolg−1 cat (3.05Ni6.1CoAl), the XRD pattern revealed the formation of Ni-Co alloy phase (Co3Ni7)0.4. However, with a further increase in the total metal loading to 11.1 mmolg−1 cat the diffraction peaks shifted towards a higher 2θ value along with the appearance of a new peak at 2θ of 62.43°, representing a decrease in the formation of Ni-Co alloy. Therefore, it can be concluded that the formation of Ni-Co alloy also depends on the total metal loading of Ni and Co in the catalyst. H2-TPR profiles of supported xNiyCoAl catalysts are exhibited in Fig. 2 (a) and Tmax values are listed in Table 1. For the comparison purpose, H2-TPR profiles of bulk NiO and Co3O4 were given in Fig. S3. The H2-TPR profile of 9.2NiAl catalyst displays a weak shoulder at 605 K and a broad peak with a maxima at around 733 K associated with the reduction of bulk NiO and dispersed NiO to Ni [26,40]. The reduction profile of 9.2CoAl possesses one broad reduction peaks with two maxima at 613 and 714 K along with a weak shoulder at 854 K. The low-temperature peaks at 613 K and 714 K corresponds to the two-step reduction of Co3O4 to CoO and CoO to metallic Co [41]. The high-temperature reduction peak at 854 K is assigned to the reduction of cobalt aluminate (Co2AlO4) [28]. The diffraction peaks corresponding to the cubic phase of CoAl2O4 was also noticed in the XRD pattern of 9.2CoAl catalyst. Moreover, the reduction profile of 9.2CoAl catalyst is stretched over high-temperature range (613−854 K) compared to 9.2NiAl catalyst (605−733 K), which suggests a strong interaction between Co species and Al2O3 support. With the addition of Ni, the reduction peaks of xNiyCoAl catalysts have been shifted towards lower temperatures as compared to the monometallic counterpart. For example, the H2-TPR profile of 1.8Ni7.3CoAl catalyst (Ni/Co mole ratio of 1:4) appeared to be similar to 9.2CoAl catalyst with the reduction peaks at 588 K and 732 K shifted to lower temperature. The lowering of reduction temperature in presence of the second reducible metal oxide was also reported previously [42]. In the present case, the proximal second reducible metal oxide, nickel potentially assists the reduction of cobalt oxide or vice versa resulting in a lowering of reduction temperature of xNiyCoAl catalysts [19]. The broad reduction peak at 588 K might be because of the simultaneous reduction of nickel-cobalt oxide spinel phase, first step reduction of weakly associated Co3O4 to CoO and NiO to Ni. Whereas, the appearance of the reduction peak at 732 K was because of the second step reduction of CoO to Co and well dispersed NiO to Ni [43]. The absence of the high-temperature reduction peak associated with the reduction of CoAl2O4 and or NiAl2O4 indicates that the introduction of Ni (or vice versa) reduces the possibility of the formation of nickel and cobalt aluminates in xNiyCoAl catalysts [42]. A further increase in Ni content or Ni/Co mole ratio to 1/3 (2.3Ni6.9CoAl) shifted further the reduction peaks towards lower temperature along with the appearance of a weak shoulder at 548 K. The low-temperature broad shoulder appeared at 548 K is assigned to the reduction of bulk NiO and Co3O4 and the reduction peak at 580 K might be related to the reduction of NiCo2O4 spinel species. XRD results also suggested the formation of NiCo2O4 spinel species with the increase in the Ni/Co mole ratio due to the strong mutual interaction between Ni and Co species. Further increasing the Ni/Co mole ratio to 1/2 (3.05Ni6.1CoAl) resulted in a sharp reduction peak at 573 K and a shoulder at 539 K. The absence of high-temperature peaks in the reduction profile of 3.05Ni6.1CoAl suggests that this particular sample is highly reducible among the other samples in the series which might be due to the presence of high concentration of NiCo2O4 spinel as compared to NiO and Co3O4 [36,44]. Consequently, the low-temperature shoulder at 539 K can be assigned to the octahedrally coordinated bulk NiO species (NiO to Niδ+) and a sharp reduction peak at 573 K is attributed to the reduction of NiCo2O4 spinel phase [26,45]. Moreover, the H2-TPR profile of 4.6Ni4.6CoAl catalyst (Ni:Co = 1:1)) displayed broad reduction peaks with maxima at 565 K and 736 K together with a shoulder at a lower temperature of 515 K. Such broad peak represents the simultaneous reduction of different Ni and Co oxide species because of the decreased interaction between Ni and Co species at higher Ni/Co mole ratio. The low-temperature shoulder is appeared because of the reduction of bulk NiO. Whereas, the broad reduction peaks with maxima at 565 K and 736 K corresponds to the simultaneous reduction of Co3O4 to Co and dispersed NiO to Ni. Further, increasing the Ni content to 7.3Ni1.8CoAl leads to the disappearance of low-temperature shoulder and the H2-TPR profile consists of a broad reduction peaks centered at 624 K and 753 K, respectively suggesting the reduction of Co3O4 and NiO species over a narrow temperature window. Therefore, the H2-TPR profile of Ni-Co catalysts suggested the formation of NiCo2O4 spinel with a relatively small amount of NiO at a Ni/Co mole ratio more ratio of 1:2. The H2-TPR profile of Ni-Co catalysts with various total metal loading from 0.9 to 11.1 mmolg−1 cat at a constant Ni/Co molar ratio of 1:2 are shown in Fig. 2(b). The H2-TPR profile of catalyst with a total metal loading of 0.9 mmolg−1 cat (0.3Ni0.6CoAl) exhibits only reduction peak at 583 K, which reflects the presence of single reducible Ni and Co species over the alumina support. The catalyst with 1.8 mmolg−1 cat (0.6Ni1.2CoAl) metal loading showed TPR profile similar to 0.9 mmolg−1 cat (0.3Ni0.6CoAl) with peak maxima at a slightly higher temperature of 587 K. The shift of reduction temperature to higher temperature with increase in metal loading was observed previously [46]. However, with a further increase in total metal loadings, the reduction of nickel and cobalt species occurs over two distinct regions. The first reduction zone around 550 K corresponds to the reduction of loosely bound NiO and Co3O4 species. The second broad reduction temperature zone (600−700 K) is attributed to the reduction of highly dispersed NiO and Co3O4 species. Interestingly, the second broad reduction zone is becoming sharper, whereas the first reduction zone disappears with further increase in the total metal loading of the catalyst. Such reduction behavior with a gradual increase in metal loading suggests the formation of an easily reducible mixed oxide (NiCo2O4) and the concentration of this reducible species was noted to increase with the increase in total loading in the catalyst. The presence of a sharp peak with higher H2 consumption at 573 K was observed in the sample with 9.2 mmog−1 cat of total metal loading (3.05Ni6.1CoAl) indicates the occurrence of higher proportion of reducible NiCo2O4 species. Moreover, a shoulder showed at 539 K is due to the presence of bulk NiO. However, further increase in total metal loading to 11.1 mmolg−1 cat, a broad peak centered at 562 K was observed which indicates reduction of multiple reducible species simultaneously. Therefore, the catalyst with a total metal loading of 9.2 mmolg−1 cat confirms the presence of easily reducible NiCo2O4 mixed oxide with higher proportion. Thus, one can visualize NiCo2O4 mixed oxide as a precursor for the formation of Ni-Co alloy in 3.05Ni6.1CoAl during the reduction of the catalyst. The formation of Ni-Co alloy was also confirmed by XRD of the reduced catalyst. The H2-TPR profile of the 3.05Ni6.1CoAl catalyst calcined at different temperatures is presented in Fig. S4. The reduction profile of the sample calcined at 623 K and 673 K was almost similar and exhibited a sharp peak at around 509 K followed by a broad reduction peak at 560 K and a high-temperature shoulder at 683 K. The low temperature and sharp reduction peak at 509 K correspond to the reduction of weakly associated bulk NiO to Ni. The broad reduction peak at 560 K is related to the first step reduction of Co3O4 to CoO and well-dispersed NiO species. Whereas, the high-temperature shoulder at 690 K is appeared due to the second step reduction of CoO to Co. The disappearance of low-temperature reduction peak and high reduction temperature shoulder, together with the increase in the intensity of second reduction peak were observed with the rise in calcination temperature till 723 K. This is probably due to the difference in interaction between Ni and Co species at different calcination temperature. The 3.05Ni6.1CoAl723 catalyst exhibits a sharp reduction peak at 573 K which suggests a stronger interaction between Ni and Co at a calcination temperature of 723 K leading to the formation of the NiCo2O4 spinel phase. NiCo2O4 is a metastable species formed as a result of strong interaction between Co and Ni species and tends to breaks down at higher temperature to NiO and Co3O4 [42,47]. With further rise in the calcination temperature beyond 723 K, the H2-TPR profile was observed to be broad, indicating the presence of various reducible species. Also, in some previous studies, it was reported that partial decomposition of NiCo2O4 spinel into NiO can happen above 673−773 K [48,49]. Therefore, the disappearance of low-temperature reduction peak of NiO, increase in the width of the second peak, and appearance of a hump at higher temperature suggests the decomposition of less thermally stable NiCo2O4 spinel oxide into NiO, Co3O4, and CoAl2O4 [42,47]. The IR spectra of calcined alumina supported Ni-Co catalysts were collected as shown in Fig. 3 . The IR bands appeared below 1000 cm−1 correspond to metal-oxygen stretching vibrations in metal oxides lattice. The monometallic 9.2CoAl catalyst shows IR bands at 572 and 667 cm−1 attributed to CoO vibrations at tetrahedral and octahedral sites in the spinel Co3O4 lattice, respectively [50–53]. As the Ni content or Ni/Co mole ratio increased, the IR bands corresponding to CoO vibrations gradually shifted towards lower wavenumber and completely disappeared in the samples with and beyond the equimolar ratio of Ni and Co (4.6Ni4.6CoAl). Therefore, the presence of IR bands at 569 and 659 cm−1 for the samples with Ni/Co mole ratio of 1:2 (3.05Ni6.1CoAl) indicates the absence of Co3O4 in its native form and supports its interaction with Ni to form NiCo2O4 mixed oxide. The formation of NiCo2O4 species in 3.05Ni6.1CoAl catalyst was also confirmed by XRD and TPR studies, which were discussed earlier. These results also affirm that Ni/Co mole ratio plays an essential role for the formation of NiCo2O4 mixed oxides. The IR spectra of the 3.05Ni6.1CoAl catalyst calcined at various temperatures were acquired under ambient condition to comprehend the nature of interaction exist between Ni and Co species, and the spectra are presented in Fig. S5. With the rise in calcination temperature from 623 K to 773 K, the position of IR bands at 572 and 667 cm−1 corresponding to Co-O vibrations from tetrahedral and octahedral sites were slightly shifted towards lower wavenumber ca. 569 and 659 cm−1. Such a redshift in the wavenumber might be due to the formation of NiCo2O4 species because of the strong interaction prevailing between Ni and Co species. The IR band in 3.05Ni6.1CoAl723 catalyst was also weak and broad which shows low crystallinity or small crystals of Co oxide species. The formation of the NiCo2O4 spinel phase in high proportion particularly at a calcination temperature of 723 K was also perceived in XRD and H2-TPR studies. However, a further rise in calcination temperature above 773 K leads to the partial decomposition of NiCo2O4 which was evident with the shifting IR bands toward higher wavenumber. The amount of surface acid sites present in reduced xNiyCoAl catalysts was determined by NH3-TPD analysis. The NH3-TPD profile of reduced catalysts with different Ni/Co mole ratio and the amount of desorbed NH3 are shown in Fig. 4 and Table 2 , respectively. Based on the evolution of the NH3 desorption peak with respect to temperature, the surface acidic sites can be divided into three types: weak (423−523 K), medium strength (523−693 K) and strong acid sites (693−1023 K) [19]. The NH3-TPD profile of bare alumina displayed a broad desorption peak above 800 K indicating presence of high amount of strong acid sites. At relatively high temperature (above 873 K), the alumina undergoes hydroxylation reaction and therefore, presence of strong acid sites in bare alumina is unlikely. The alumina supported Ni, Co and Ni-Co catalyst exhibit higher total acidity as compared to bare alumina indicating generation of acid sites upon interaction of metals with the support or due to metal-metal interaction. Compared to NH3-TPD profile of bare alumina, the 0.9NiAl catalyst exhibited a broad desorption peak with a maximum at 581 K suggesting the presence of medium strength acid sites. The second peak at high temperature (906 K) represents the desorption of NH3 from strong acid sites [54]. Although the generation of medium and strong strength acid sites is not fully understood, this sort of acidity may be generated via high temperature dehydration of protonated oxide bridges during calcination or reduction steps [18]. Zhang et al. also reported the presence of a considerable amount of weak, medium and strong acid sites on the surface of Ni/γ-Al2O3 [12]. It could also be seen that a higher amount of weak acid sites were present in 9.1CoAl catalyst, which might be generated by the impregnation of Co metal into the alumina matrix or maybe due to the air oxidation of metallic cobalt. The quantity of these acid sites varied with the Co and Ni mole ratio. The ammonia desorption profiles for bimetallic xCoyNi/γ-Al2O3 catalysts were found to be very broad that can be deconvoluted to many peaks. The new desorption peak associated with medium strength acid sites originates because of the increase of Ni/Co mole ratio or Ni content, while the high temperature desorption peaks related to strong acid sites shifted towards lower temperature. Again, the medium strength acid sites begin to shift towards lower temperature with the increase in Ni content or Ni/Co mole ratio. The higher amount of medium strength acid sites was formed in the catalyst with Ni/Co mol ratio of 1:2 and 1:1. In addition, the total acid sites was observed to increase with the decrease in Ni/Co mole ratio or Co amount till the Ni/Co mole ratio of 1:2. This result reflects that the coexistence of Ni and Co species on the γ-Al2O3 and their synergetic effect affect significantly the distribution of acidic sites in the catalyst [55]. The 6.05Ni6.1CoAl773 catalyst exhibited the highest amount of acid sites, which can be accounted due to the synergy between Ni and Co species leading to the formation Ni-Co alloy in higher fraction. The modulation in the acidity of catalyst have also been observed over alumina supported copper-nickel catalyst due to the synergistic effect of Ni and Cu [56]. The weak and medium acid sites, which are observed in supported Ni-Co catalysts act as the active sites and contribute to hydrogenolysis of the CO bond as discussed later. 3.2 HDO of guaiacol The HDO of guaiacol was performed in a high pressure and temperature batch reactor under wide range of temperatures (623–823 K), initial H2 pressure (2.5−15 bar H2), and catalyst loading (0.25−1 wt%) using xNiyCoAl catalysts to understand the effect of these parameters on HDO of guaiacol. The effect of Ni/Co mole ratio, total metal loading and calcination/reduction temperature on HDO of guaiacol and product distribution were also investigated. The gaseous and liquid product formed at different reaction conditions using xNiyCoAl catalysts were identified and quantified. There were some unidentified products persisted in the products mixture. However, contribution of these unidentified products was much less and of the order of 5−10 wt%. The standard chromatograms of liquid and gaseous products are presented in Fig. S6 and S7, respectively. The liquid phase comprised of a variety of compounds such as phenol, veratrole, anisole, cresol, benzene, cyclohexanol, cyclohexanone, cyclohexene, cyclohexane and methanol. In the gas phase methane was only product detected and the formation of hydrogen could not be verified as HDO of guaiacol was performed in presence of hydrogen. These results are consistent with the guaiacol HDO studied by Dongil et al. for NiCu/C catalyst, Bykova et al. for NiCu/SiO2-ZrO2, Fang et al. for Ni-Fe/CNT catalyst [15,57,58]. A comprehensive discussion on HDO of guaiacol are given in the subsequent section considering various process parameters and different xNiyCoAl catalysts. 3.2.1 Effect of Ni/Co mole ratio The effect of the variation of Ni/Co mole ratio in xNiyCoAl catalysts on guaiacol conversion and product distribution is demonstrated in Fig. 5 . To better understand the effect of Ni/Co mole ratio on the catalytic performance, the TOF values were calculated based on metallic dispersion and the results are summarized in Table S5. The monometallic 9.2CoAl catalyst with a TOF value of 1.76 h−1 was found to be more active for guaiacol HDO as compared to 9.2NiAl catalyst (TOF = 1.54 h−1). A guaiacol conversion of 95 % with cyclohexane (21 %), cyclohexene (33 %), phenol (20 %) and benzene (10 %) were observed as the primary products over 9.2CoAl catalyst. The higher activity of 9.2CoAl catalyst was due to the inherent oxophilicity of Co metal, which lend weak Lewis acid sites as observed in NH3-TPD analysis. However, HYD route is always favored when phenolic compounds are dissociatively absorbed over the metallic surface [59]. This results an increased in negative charge on the carbon atoms in β position of aromatic ring, which contributes to the protonation of the aromatic ring in comparison with non-dissociative adsorption. In previous reports, both DDO and HYD have been found to favored over Co surface [59]. Whereas guaiacol conversion of 79 % with cyclohexane (44 %), phenol (17 %), and benzene (13 %) as the primary product was achieved with 9.2NiAl catalyst under similar reaction condition. The higher selectivity of aromatic ring saturated product over 9.2NiAl catalyst clearly demonstrate high hydrogenation capability of pure metallic Ni than Co. The selectivities of the HDO products over 9.2NiAl and 9.2CoAl were also compared at the similar conversion level of ∼40 %. The 9.2NiAl was found to have a higher selectivity for cyclohexane (28.4 %) whereas phenol (49.2 %) was the major HDO product over 9.2CoAl confirming the higher ring hydrogenation capability of Ni metal as compared to Co (Fig. S8). The Ni-Co catalysts showed better performance during guaiacol HDO as compared to respective monometallic one. The guaiacol conversion was noticed to enhance with the increase in Ni content up to Ni/Co mole ratio of 1:2 and declined thereafter. The 3.05Ni6.1CoAl catalyst (Ni/Co mole ratio = 1:2) showed substantially higher guaiacol conversion (99 %) with cyclohexane (56 %) and benzene (29 %) as the primary products. A closer analysis of the variation in the selectivity of aromatic products (benzene) represents that it passed through a maximum at the Ni/Co mole ratio of 1:2 (Fig. 6 ). These results indicate that the increased Ni-Co bimetallic sites in 3.05Ni6.1CoAl works synergistically with the active site structure, increasing HDO activity and selectivity for aromatic products (benzene). Consequently, TOF value on 3.05Ni6.1CoAl catalyst was increased to maximum value (2.21 h−1), indicating that the effect of particle size also exists on the formation of catalytically active sites for the HDO of guaiacol. These results also highlight crucial role of neighboring Ni-Co bimetallic sites for the adsorption of phenolic compounds and subsequent cleavage of CO bond. However, to explain the catalytic behavior, other data such as hydrogen activation capability and acidity should also be considered. Thus, it can be inferred that the Ni/Co mole ratio has strong influence on the formation of catalytically active surface species and also the activity of xNiyCoAl catalysts. The higher activity of 3.05Ni6.1CoAl catalyst suggests that there exists an optimal Ni/Co mole ratio that leads to the formation of NiCo2O4 mixed oxide in higher proportion [36]. Upon reduction in H2, NiCo2O4 mixed oxide leads to the formation of Ni-Co alloy with different electronic properties which is responsible for observed changes in activity and selectivity [60]. Analysis of NH3-TPD results also indicated the presence of higher and medium strength and total acidity in 3.05Ni6.1CoAl as compared to other catalyst in the series. A further increase or decrease in the mole ratio of Ni/Co breaks the stoichiometry required for the formation of NiCo2O4 mixed oxide, and therefore, concentration of Ni-Co alloys decreases resulted in the decline in the acidity and activity of the catalyst. These results are also consistent with the XRD and H2-TPR results as discussed earlier. H2-TPR profile of 3.05Ni6.1CoAl catalyst suggests the presence of higher proportion of NiCo2O4 mixed oxide than NiO and Co3O4, and XRD pattern of reduced catalyst confirmed the presence of Ni-Co alloyed phase. Over Ni-Co bimetallic catalyst, the metallic Ni activates the H2 molecule, whereas Ni-Co alloy provide oxophilic sites for the adsorption of guaiacol coordinating with an oxygen atom [61]. The activated H2 molecule then interacts with the oxygen atom and facilitates the hydrogenolysis of CAr-O linkage. The occurrence of higher fraction of Ni-Co alloy on 3.05Ni6.1CoAl catalyst is ascribed to its superior activity during guaiacol HDO. The Ni-Co alloy promote the activation of CAr−OCH3, and CAr−OH linkage, thereby enhances the selectivity towards aromatic products. Therefore, in terms of TOF value, selectivity of the deoxygenated products (cyclohexane and benzene) and guaiacol conversion, 3.05Ni6.1CoAl catalyst showed to be more attractive therefore this catalyst was chosen for further investigations. 3.2.2 Effect of total metal loading The combined total metal loadings of Ni and Co over γ-Al2O3 were varied from 0.9 to 11.1 mmolg−1 cat with a constant Ni/Co molar ratio of 1:2. The effect of total metal loading on the guaiacol conversion and product distribution was investigated and the results are presented in Fig. 6. The guaiacol conversion over xNiyCoAl catalysts was enhanced sharply with the rise in total metal loading and nearly complete guaiacol conversion (100 %) was obtained with total metal loadings of 9.2 mmolg−1 cat (3.05Ni6.1CoAl) and then leveled off after that. It is worth mentioning that the selectivity towards completely deoxygenated products such as cyclohexane and benzene was found to increase linearly from 23 % to 56 % and 10%–29% up to a total metal loading of 9.2 mmog−1 cat and then decreases afterward. Then again, the selectivity of phenol was noted to decrease gradually from 23 % to a minimum of 3 % at a total metal loading 9.2 mmog−1 cat. The decline in the selectivity of phenol was because of its conversion to cyclohexane through DHY-HYD pathway or to benzene through DDO pathway. The DDO pathway primarily occurs over Ni-Co alloy. The enhanced selectivity towards benzene for 3.05Ni6.1CoAl catalyst may be because of the formation of a higher proportion of Ni-Co alloy, which acts as the active sites for DMO/DDO pathway. The XRD and H2-TPR results also confirmed the existence of higher proportion of NiCo2O4 spinel phase in oxide catalyst and Ni-Co alloyed phase in the reduced catalyst with a total metal loading of 9.2 mmolg−1 cat. Therefore, 3.05Ni6.1CoAl catalyst with a total metal loading of 9.2 mmog−1 cat was deemed as optimal metal loading for further catalytic studies. 3.2.3 Effect of calcination and reduction temperature The effect of calcination and reduction temperature on the activity of 3.05Ni6.1CoAl catalyst during guaiacol HDO was studied by calcining and reducing the catalyst at five different temperatures (623 K, 673 K, 723 K, 773 K, and 823 K). The HDO of guaiacol was carried out at reaction temperature of 573 K and 10 bar of initial H2 pressure for 4 h and the results are presented in Fig. 7 . The calcination and reduction temperature had inappreciable effect on the conversion of guaiacol and all the catalysts perceived around 99 % conversion. However, the reduction temperature was found to effect significantly the product distribution during guaiacol HDO over 3.05Ni6.1CoAl catalyst. The selectivity of benzene was observed to reach a maximum of 29 % at calcination and reduction temperature of 723 K and then decline with further increase in calcination and reduction temperature. On the other hand, the selectivity of cyclohexane was enhanced from 55 % to 59 % with the rise in the calcination and reduction temperature from 623 to 823 K. The change in the selectivity of the hydrogenated and aromatic products such as cyclohexane and benzene might be related to the phase transformation of active metal/metal oxides during thermal treatment. The change in the oxides/metallic phases with the calcination temperature has been discussed in XRD and TPR studies. The H2-TPR profile suggests the presence of a higher proportion of complex oxide NiCo2O4 spinel phase in 3.05Ni6.1CoAl723. The uniform distribution of Ni and Co in the complex oxide can lead to the formation of Ni-Co alloy during reduction. Therefore, the presence of abundant Ni-Co alloy in reduced 3.05Ni6.1CoAl catalyst resulted in higher selectivity of benzene. On the other hand, an increase in heat treatment causes segregation of NiO resulting in the formation of Co-rich off-stoichiometric NiCo2O4 spinel [62]. Hence, higher reduction temperature increases the proportion of metallic Ni which is responsible for hydrogenation of the aromatic ring leading to higher selectivity for cyclohexane. Considering the higher guaiacol conversion and higher selectivity for benzene because of controlled hydrogenation capability, a calcination and reduction temperature of 723 K was chosen for further studies. 3.2.4 Effect of reaction temperature The effect of reaction temperature on the HDO of guaiacol was investigated over a temperature range of 473−598 K catalyzed by reduced 3.05Ni6.1CoAl catalyst at an initial H2 pressure of 10 bar. The guaiacol conversion and selectivity of various products are presented in Fig. 8 . It could be observed that the conversion of guaiacol was significantly increased from 10 % to 99.5 % with the increase in reaction temperature and almost reached a plateau at 573 K with a constant reaction time of 4 h. When the HDO of guaiacol was investigated at 473 K, 10 % guaiacol conversion was accomplished with cyclohexanol (41 %), phenol (22 %), and catechol (17 %) as the major product. These results collaborated well with the Zhou et al. study where they also reported a higher selectivity for cyclohexanol (68 %) with 96 % guaiacol conversion at 473 K under a high initial H2 pressure of 50 bar after 8 h over (10 + 10)% Ni-Co/γ-Al2O3 [19] (Table 3 , Entry 1). Herein, an increase in the reaction temperature to 498 K resulted in 19 % guaiacol conversion with cyclohexanol (51 %) and phenol (30 %) as the major products with reduced amount of catechol (7%). The above results indicate that DME is the primary pathway during the conversion of guaiacol over 3.05Ni6.1CoAl catalyst with catechol as an intermediate. When HDO of guaiacol was performed at 523 K, 50 % of guaiacol was converted, and the reaction products were mainly cyclohexanol (48 %) and phenol (26 %). However, when the temperature increased to 548 K, the conversion of guaiacol reached 95 % with cyclohexanol (27 %), cyclohexane (26 %), benzene (14 %) and phenol (11 %) turns out to be the major HDO products. With a further increase in reaction temperature to 573 K, almost complete conversion of guaiacol was achieved with cyclohexane (56 %) and benzene (29 %) as the major products. Therefore, the increase in selectivity towards aromatic products primarily benzene was noted to increase with the increase in reaction temperature. This might be because of the higher bond energy of CAr−OH bond. Gutierrez et al. also suggested that higher deoxygenation reaction rather than hydrogenation reaction would occur at higher reaction temperature which resulted in increased selectivity towards aromatic products [63]. Our results indicate that the DMO of guaiacol to phenol and DDO of phenol to benzene might happen on the Ni-Co alloy at relatively higher reaction temperature, thus increasing the selectivity towards benzene. Considering the conversion and selectivity of benzene, a temperature of 573 K was taken as the suitable temperature for further studies. 3.2.5 Effect of initial H2 pressure The influence of initial H2 pressure on the activity of 3.05Ni6.1CoAl catalyst during HDO of guaiacol was studied by carrying out the reactions at different initial H2 pressures (2.5, 5, 7.5, 10, 12.5 and 15 bar). The dependency of guaiacol conversion and product selectivity with initial H2 pressures is presented in Fig. 9 . A control experiment under inert atmosphere (20 bar N2) was also carried out and ∼ 15 % conversion of guaiacol was achieved. The phenol, catechol and veratrole were obtained as the major products with a selectivity of around 50 %, 25 % and 19 %. Therefore, it can be established that under the inert condition, the HDO of guaiacol proceeds through DME pathway where hydrogen required for CArO−CH3 bond hydrogenolysis was provided by the hydrogen-donating solvent, tetraline. The presence of H2 in the gaseous phase was confirmed and thereby supports this statement. An initial H2 pressure of 2.5 bar caused a drastic increase in the conversion of guaiacol and affected the product distribution as well. The conversion of guaiacol was increased from 15 % to 98 % with the initial hydrogen pressure of 2.5 bar which was almost the lowest reaction pressures compared to other HDO studies of guaiacol over non-noble catalysts [19,64,65] (Table 3). With the further increase in initial H2 pressure, the hydrogenation of the aromatic ring and the subsequent deoxygenation process occurs simultaneously. As a result, the selectivity for the saturated products such as cyclohexane was observed to increase gradually from 0% at 20 bar initial N2 pressure to 62 % at 15 bar of initial H2 pressure. The selectivity for the aromatic product benzene was observed to increase to a maximum of 27.3 % at 5 bar H2 pressure and further increase in initial H2 pressure almost had no effect. Therefore, for further studies on the HDO of guaiacol, all reactions were performed at an initial H2 pressure of 5 bar with all other conditions held constant. 3.2.6 Effect of catalyst loading The effect of the catalyst loading (w/v %) on the HDO of guaiacol was investigated at 573 K with an initial H2 pressure of 5 bar. The product distribution obtained after 4 h of reaction time are shown in Fig. 10 . Guaiacol was not converted in absence of the catalyst at similar reaction conditions. Whereas, almost complete guaiacol conversion was attained with 0.25 % (w/v) catalyst loading which shows the high HDO activity of 3.05Ni6.1CoAl catalyst. No changes in the guaiacol conversion were observed with the further increase in catalyst loading. However, product distribution was found to vary with the catalyst loading. The selectivity of benzene was noticed to increase from 27.3 % to 35.2 % and cyclohexane from 47.5 % to and 59.1 %, respectively with an increase in catalyst loading from 0.25 % (w/v) to 0.75 % (w/v) and afterward remained constant. Whereas, the other intermediates such as phenol and cyclohexene were completely converted to benzene and cyclohexane at 0.75 % (w/v) of catalyst loading. The increase in the selectivity towards benzene as well as cyclohexane suggest the increase in the active sites responsible for DDO as well as HYD-DHY reaction with the increase in catalyst loading. Based on powder XRD and H2-TPR results, there is a possibility for the presence of Ni metallic sites along with Ni-Co alloys in 3.05Ni6.1CoAl catalyst. However, presence of metallic nickel was not ascertain by characterization results may be because of the low concentrations of metallic nickel. The increase in the Ni metallic sites with the increase in the catalyst amount might be responsible for HYD-DHY reaction forming cyclohexane while a simultaneous increase in Ni-Co alloy increases the selectivity towards benzene via DMO pathway. An excellent maximum selectivity of 35 % towards benzene was obtained with 3.05Ni6.1CoAl at 0.75 % (w/v) catalyst loading, which wes the best HDO result achieved with the non-noble bimetallic Ni-Co catalyst [19,64,65] (Table 3). 4 Reproducibility and recyclability The reproducibility of 3.05Ni6.1CoAl catalyst during HDO of guaiacol was examined by performing four different runs under similar reaction conditions (Table S6). Almost identical guaiacol conversion and product distribution were obtained for the reproduced experimental runs. These results confirm the repeatability of the experiments conducted during HDO of guaiacol over Ni-Co catalysts. The recyclability evaluation was performed by repeatedly using a batch of 3.05Ni6.1CoAl catalyst acquired during the reproducibility study. The spent catalyst obtained after filtering the reaction mixture was washed repeatedly (3–4 times) with ethanol to remove the adsorbed organic compounds and then heated at 383 K for 12 h. The dried catalyst was then used for recycling catalytic cycle under the optimal conditions of 573 K, 5 bar initial H2 pressure and 0.75 % (w/v) catalyst loading. The guaiacol conversion and product selectivity obtained after the recycling test is described in Table S6. No change regarding the conversion of guaiacol was observed over spent 3.05Ni6.1CoAl catalyst. However, the selectivity of benzene and cyclohexane reduced to 24.5 % and 49.6 % from 35.1 % and 59.1 % with respect to fresh catalysts. Further comparing the product distribution obtained in reproducibility and recyclability studies, it was also noticed that only selectivity of intermediate products (anisole, phenol, cyclohexanol, cyclohexanone and cyclohexene) increased during HDO of guaiacol with spent catalyst (Table S6). These intermediate products were formed following DDO/DME and stepwise hydrogenation-dehydration reaction of corresponding intermediate as discussed in the following section in detail. Specifically, moderate oxophilic sites (Ni-Co alloy species) favors the DDO reaction. These results clearly indicate the loss and or deactivation of active sites responsible for DDO and hydrogenation-dehydration reaction leading to decrease in selectivity of benzene and cyclohexane. A comprehensive characterization is essential to unravel the structural property change that may happen during reaction. However, comprehensive characterization of spent catalyst was not performed in the present study and can be considered as future study. 5 Reaction mechanism The activation and cleavage of three different types of CO linkages present in the molecular structure of guaiacol determine its transformation pathway over a catalyst. The bond energy of various CO bonds in guaiacol decreases in the following order: CAr−OH (phenolic hydroxyl, 414 kJ mol−1) > CAr−OCH3 (methoxy group, 356 kJ mol−1) > CArO−CH3 (methyl, 247 kJ mol−1) [66]. Therefore, mainly three catalytic reaction pathways could be followed during the HDO of guaiacol (i) Demethylation (DME) (ii) Demethoxylation (DMO) and (iii) Direct deoxygenation (DDO) [67]. During the DME pathway, the hydrogenolysis of methyl oxygen (CArO−CH3) linkage in guaiacol leads to the production of one mole of catechol and methane which was already confirmed by Zhou et al [64]. The reaction then proceeds with the elimination of one of the hydroxyl groups of catechol to produce phenol. Whereas, the second pathway progresses with the cleavage of methoxy-aromatic carbon linkage (CAr−OCH3) to generate phenol and methanol and avoids the formation of catechol. This pathway is commonly known as the direct demethoxylation pathway (DMO) [58]. The phenol so generated from the above pathways may then subsequently undergo either direct deoxygenation to generate benzene or step-wise hydrogenation-dehydration (HYD-DHY) to give cyclohexanol, cyclohexanone, cyclohexene and cyclohexane which was also observed by Bykova et al. [58]. Moreover, compared to previous studies, guaiacol in the third reaction pathway can also transform to anisole and H2O via hydrogenolysis of CAr−OH linkage which is thermodynamically less favorable due to the high bond dissociation energy [68,69]. The capability of a catalyst to follow a particular pathway during guaiacol HDO depends on various factors such as process parameters, type of metal (s) phase and its composition, type of support etc. [70]. Herein, the reactivity of Ni-Co bimetallic catalysts was tested in the HDO of guaiacol in a batch reactor under a wide range of process parameters and varying active metallic compositions. The primary deoxygenated products obtained over Ni-Co bimetallic catalysts were cyclohexane and benzene which was different than the Zhou’s research, reporting the cyclohexanol as the major product during the HDO of guaiacol over Ni-Co/γ-Al2O3 [19,64]. In literature, it has been reported that Ni-Co bimetallic catalyst are more active than monometallic Ni particularly due to the acidity [19,64]. Our results showed that Ni-Co alloy was formed and renders an optimal absorption strength of guaiacol over Ni-Co alloy at certain composition. Considering the selectivity of various products formed under different reaction conditions and catalyst composition, a possible reaction pathway is depicted in Fig. 11 and Scheme 1 . The characterization results of Ni-Co bimetallic catalysts revealed important information about the structure of the catalyst and the presence of various surface species involved in the HDO of guaiacol. The monometallic Ni catalysts promotes hydrogenation of the aromatic ring due to the high hydrogenation capability of the Ni metal [71]. Incorporation of Co in Ni-Co catalysts decreases the electron donating properties from d-orbital, altering the activity of the catalysts and successively observe to decrease the hydrogenation of aromatic ring of guaiacol [57]. The Ni/Co mole ratio has crucial role to play in the formation of different oxide species, which are responsible for improved activity of Ni-Co bimetallic catalysts. The bimetallic catalyst with total metal loading of 9.2 mmolg−1 cat and Ni/Co mole ratio of 1:2 (3.05Ni6.1CoAl) was found to be highly active with controlled hydrogenation ability leading to highest selectivity of aromatic product, i.e. benzene. The enhanced catalytic activity of 3.05Ni6.1CoAl catalyst was due to surface reconstruction and interaction between surface Ni and Co species resulting in the formation of NiCo2O4 mixed oxide, which is the precursor for the formation Ni-Co alloy during reduction in presence of hydrogen. The formation of NiCo2O4 mixed oxide and Ni-Co alloy was confirmed by XRD and TPR. The alloying nickel and cobalt has synergistic effect on the catalytic activity and selectivity to the targeted product possibly because of the change in electron density as a result of the formation of heteronuclear metal-metal bond [72]. Ni-Co alloy provides a different adsorption site than pure Ni and Co with new electron density, which imparts Lewis acidity (confirmed by NH3-TPD) in turn affecting the chemisorption capacity of the guaiacol and other intermediates during guaiacol HDO [73]. In bimetallic catalysts, the HDO of guaiacol proceeds via adsorption of guaiacol over metallic Co with the oxygen atom of CAr-O−CH3 linkage due to the stronger affinity of Co for oxygen species than Ni [74]. The oxophilicity of metal is related to the position of D-band center associated with the Fermi level, which also depends on the nature of metal and its degree of co-ordination. Because of the close proximity of D-band center to the Fermi level, the anti-bonding hybridized orbital of metal and oxygen is farther away from the Fermi level resulting in low electron occupancy [75]. Consequently, the MO bond becomes more stronger, and the metal becomes more oxophilic. The oxophilicity of Ni, Co and Ni-Co alloyed species follows this particular order: Co > Ni-Co > Ni. The more oxophilic site strongly binds to oxygen of phenolic compound resulting in enhance activity for the DDO reaction. However, the subsequent hydrogenation reaction promoted by the hydride transfer weaken and rupture the metal-oxygen bond to reconstitute the clean active site for subsequent catalytic cycle [76]. This step is disfavored on the more strong oxophilic site. The binding energy for the most stable O* on the bare Co (111) is -550 kJmol−1, whereas that on bare Ni is -496 kJmol−1 [61]. The metal hydrides are generated through the dissociation of molecular H2 to active hydrogen species over Ni metallic centers [27]. The activation and cleavage of CArO−CH3 bond initiated by hydride transfer resulting in the formation of catechol and methane following DME pathway. The catechol so generated subsequently undergo hydrogenolysis to form phenol instead of dearomatization to 1,2-cyclohexanediol as reported by Zhou et al. [19,64]. On the other hand, the adsorption of guaiacol over Ni-Co alloys can activate CAr−OCH3 bond and result in the formation of phenol and methanol via DMO pathway. Ni-Co alloy have lower affinity for oxygen as compared to Co clusters. Ni-Co alloy species binds to the oxygen with a much lower bond dissociation energy (-370 KJ/mol) as compared to Ni and Co species [61].Therefore, the weakly bound O atom of guaiacol retains higher proton affinity and interacts more strongly with the activated hydrogen over the catalyst surface, thereby, activates CAr−OCH3 bonds to generate −CH3OH. The generation of methane in the gaseous phase and methanol in liquid phase confirms the existence of two competitive pathways for guaiacol transformation over Ni-Co bimetallic catalyst. However, formation of methane from methanol cannot be ruled out. DME is considered as the main route with catechol as an intermediate product and DMO as the secondary pathway with phenol as an intermediate product during guaiacol HDO over Ni-Co bimetallic catalyst. In the next step, phenol transforms further to cyclohexanol through hydrogenation (HYD) of the aromatic ring over the metallic Ni sites. The metallic Ni accepts the delocalized aromatic ring electron and activates the ring which is then hydrogenated by the adsorbed H2 resulting in the formation of cyclohexanol [12]. Finally, −OH group of cyclohexanol interacts with the metal sites (Ni or Co) resulting in the formation of cyclohexene and cyclohexane through dehydration (DHY) pathway [77]. Whereas, the adsorption of phenol over Ni-Co alloy sites prevents the hydrogenation of aromatic ring resulting in the formation of benzene. The anisole was also observed in minor amount which might be generated either due to the DDO of guaiacol via activation of CAr−OH or DMO of veratrole which is formed as a result of transalkylation of guaiacol. However, the activation of CAr−OH bond in guaiacol is thermodynamically less favorable due to its high bond dissociation energy. Furthermore, traces of alkylated products such as o-cresol may form as a result of the transfer of methyl group (formed during catechol formation) to phenol [78,79]. Therefore, a synergic effect between Ni and Co in the bimetallic catalyst accounts for the higher activity and controlled hydrogenation capability of the Ni-Co bimetallic catalyst. The synergistic interaction between Ni and Co species leads to the generation of mild oxophilic Ni-Co alloy sites at appropriate total metal loading, Ni/Co mole ratio, and calcination temperature. The Ni-Co alloy can activate CAr−OCH3 and CAr−OH bonds of guaiacol and phenol thus enhancing the selectivity of aromatics (benzene) in the product stream. 6 Conclusion The catalytic performance of xNiyCoAl catalysts for the HDO of guaiacol in a high temperature and pressure batch reactor was effectively demonstrated. The XRD and H2-TPR results confirm the formation of NiCo2O4 spinel structure in the oxide catalysts due to the strong interaction between Ni and Co oxides. The formation of NiCo2O4 spinel strongly depends on the total metal loading, Ni/Co mole ratio and the calcination temperature. The NiCo2O4 spinel structure transforms to Ni-Co alloy during reduction in hydrogen. The maximum proportion of NiCo2O4 spinel structure and Ni-Co alloy formed in oxidized and reduced 3.05Ni6.1CoAl (total metal loading 9.2 mmolg−1 cat) catalysts, respectively at calcination and reduction temperature of 723 K. The NH3-TPD results indicates generation of medium strength sites upon Ni-Co alloying, which possesses different electronic properties. The catalytic performance evaluation study under different reaction conditions shows that Ni-Co bimetallic catalysts exhibit excellent catalytic activity and selectivity towards HDO of guaiacol. The dependence of xNiyCoAl catalysts performance on total metal loading, Ni/Co mole ratio, and calcination and reduction temperature shows that the highest activity was obtained with 3.05Ni6.1CoAl (total metal loading 9.2 mmolg−1 cat) catalyst calcined and reduced at 723 K. The deoxygenated products such as cyclohexane and benzene were obtained as the primary HDO products. The presence of higher fraction of Ni-Co alloy on 3.05Ni6.1CoAl (723 K) catalyst is ascribed to its superior activity during guaiacol HDO. The synergistic effect between Ni and Co (Ni-Co alloy) in the Ni-Co catalyst accounts for the higher activity and controlled hydrogenation capability. In addition, reaction temperature played also a significant role in driving the selectivity towards the desired products. The high reaction temperature favors the DMO of guaiacol and DDO of phenol resulting in higher selectivity of benzene. Thus, bimetallic catalyst derived from non-noble metals provides an alternative approach for the development of advanced HDO catalyst with higher activity, selectivity and stability. coredata.dc:description: The hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of guaiacol was investigated in a batch reactor using Ni-Co/γ-Al2O3 catalysts prepared by co-impregnation method. The structural and physicochemical properties of the catalysts were investigated using BET, XRD, H2-TPR, FT-IR, and NH3-TPD. The characterization results revealed that the formation of various Ni-Co composite species strongly depend on the Ni/Co mole ratio, total metal loadings, and the calcination/reduction temperature. The 6.1Ni3.05CoAl (Ni/Co = 1:2) catalyst seeds the formation of NiCo2O4 spinel structure and subsequent formation of Ni-Co alloy, which represents as specific active site for direct demethoxylation/deoxygenation reaction. The synergistic interaction of Ni-Co enhances the selectivity of benzene. The benzene selectivity of 35.2 % and cyclohexane selectivity of 59.1 % with complete conversion of guaiacol (98.9 %) were achieved with the 3.05Ni6.1CoAl catalyst at 575 K. A tentative reaction pathway is proposed based on the product distribution accomplished during HDO reaction. The structural property was correlated with activity to explore the mechanistic insights.
coredata.dc:title: Synergistic effect of Ni-Co alloying on hydrodeoxygenation of guaiacol over Ni-Co/Al2O3 catalysts
